''[[1995 St. Louis Rams season|1995]] in St. Louis'' |uniform = }} The '''[[1994 NFL season|1994]] [[Los Angeles Rams]] season''' was the team's 57th year with the [[National Football League]] and the 49th and final season in [[Los Angeles]]. ==Personnel== ===Staff=== {| class="toccolours" style="text-align: left;" |- ! colspan="7" style="background-color: #00338D; color: white; border: 2px solid #FECB00; text-align: center;"|'''1994 Los Angeles Rams staff''' |- | style="font-size: 95%;" valign="top" |'''Front Office''' *Owner/President â [[Georgia Frontiere]] *Executive Vice President â John Shaw *Senior Vice President â Jay Zygmunt *Administrator of Football Operations â [[Jack Faulkner]] *Director of Player Personnel â John Becker '''Head Coaches''' *Vice President/Head Coach â [[Chuck Knox]] *Assistant Head Coach/Safeties â [[Joe Vitt]] '''Offensive Coaches''' *Offensive Coordinator/Running Backs â Chick Harris *Quarterbacks â [[Mike Martz]] *Wide Receivers â Steve Moore *Tight Ends â [[Rennie Simmons]] *Offensive Line â Jim Erkenbeck *Offensive Assistant â [[Chuck Knox Jr.]] |width="35"|  |valign="top"| | style="font-size: 95%;" valign="top" | '''Defensive Coaches''' *Defensive Coordinator/Defensive Line â George Dyer *Linebackers â Dick Selcer *Defensive Backs â [[Rod Perry]] *Defensive Assistant â [[Greg Gaines]] '''Special Teams Coaches''' *Special Teams â Wayne Sevier '''Strength and Conditioning''' *Strength and Conditioning â Chris Clausen |} ==Regular season== ===Schedule=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! |} ===Standings=== {{1994 NFC West standings}} ==Relocation to St. Louis== Under the terms of the Rams' deal with Anaheim, they were to receive the rights to develop plots of land near the Stadium. When nothing came of these plans, and with attendance falling, Georgia Frontiere got permission to relocate the team. This permission was only granted after the building of the Arrowhead Pond (a multi-use sports arena for hockey and basketball) in close proximity to Anaheim Stadium. The Rams agreed to let the Pond be built within miles of Anaheim Stadium with an 'out clause' to pay the City of Anaheim an amount of money in millions to release them from the lease. After an aborted move to [[Baltimore]], the Rams moved from Los Angeles to St. Louis in late 1994, initially playing at [[Busch Memorial Stadium]] until the ([[TWA]]) Trans World Dome (now the [[Edward Jones Dome]]) was completed. The NFL owners originally rejected the moveâuntil Frontiere agreed to share some of the [[Personal seat license|permanent seat license]] revenue she was to receive from St. Louis. That same year the then-[[Oakland Raiders|Los Angeles Raiders]] were threatening to relocate as wellâand did, back to [[Oakland, California|Oakland]]. ==See also== ;Other Anaheimâbased teams in 1994 * '''[[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|California Angels]]''' ''([[Angel Stadium of Anaheim|Anaheim Stadium]])'' ** [[1994 California Angels season]] * '''[[Anaheim Ducks|Mighty Ducks of Anaheim]]''' ''([[Honda Center|Anaheim Arena/Arrowhead Pond]])'' ** [[1993â94 Mighty Ducks of Anaheim season]] ** [[1994â95 Mighty Ducks of Anaheim season]] * '''[[Los Angeles Clippers]]''' ''([[Honda Center|Arrowhead Pond of Anaheim]])'' ** [[List of Los Angeles Clippers seasons|1994â95 Los Angeles Clippers season]]* *Played Occasional Games in Anaheim ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/ram/1994.htm 1994 Los Angeles Rams Season at Pro-Football Reference] {{1994 NFL season by team}} {{Los Angeles Rams}} {{Orange County Sports}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1994 Los Angeles Rams Season}} [[Category:1994 National Football League season by team|Los Angeles Rams]] [[Category:Los Angeles Rams seasons]]
